Åshild Næss, Pers.Comm.
Ross, M. & Næss, Å. (2007). An Oceanic origin for Äiwoo, the language of the Reef Islands? Oceanic Linguistics, 46, 2.
Some entries from: Tryon, D.T. & Hackman, B. (1983) Solomon Islands languages: an internal classification.

record.annotation: to arrange things, to put things in order
"I think (about something), lit. to arrange my neck".
"chew to soften" (e.g. chewing gum; lit bite-soften)
(suck on e.g. a sweet lit bite-around)
(suck in, e.g. water through a straw, smoke from a cigarette)
to be in a standing position
tr. Literally "CAUS-die" with an extra suffix for the transitive form
(scratch at the ground, like a chicken looking for food)
(scratch at the ground, like a chicken looking for food)
(scratch off, e.g bark off a tree)
beat to make noise, e.g. a drum"
(in the sense of animal or fish meat as food)
Not a lot of lakes in the Reefs. The Gospel of Mark uses 'big (body of) fresh water'.
